Here are two spinners, A and B. Each one is a regular hexagon. For each statement, put a tick (✓) if it is true. Put a cross (✗) if it is not true. Statements: Scoring '1' is more likely on A than on B. Scoring '2' is more likely on A than on B. Scoring '3' is as equally likely on A as on B. Zara spins both spinners. The score on A is added to the score on B. She says, 'The sum of the scores on both spinners is certain to be less than 7'. Is she correct? Circle Yes or No. Explain how you know.
questions.answer: 15a: ✓ (Spinner A has 3 sections with '1', spinner B has 1 section with '1'), 15b: ✗ (Spinner A has 2 sections with '2', spinner B has 3 sections with '2'), 15c: ✓ (Both spinners have 1 section with '3' out of 6). 15d: No. The maximum score is 3 + 3 = 6, which is less than 7, but she said 'certain' which means it will always happen, but there are combinations that give less than 7 (e.g., 1+1=2), so while all sums are less than 7, the statement 'certain to be less than 7' is actually true. Accept: No - because she could get 3 on both giving 6, or Yes - the maximum is 6 which is less than 7.

questions.question: Here is a sequence of patterns made from squares and circles. Pattern 1: 1 square, 3 circles. Pattern 2: 2 squares, 5 circles. Pattern 3: 3 squares, 7 circles. The sequence continues in the same way. Calculate how many squares there will be in the pattern which has 25 circles. Show your working. You may get a mark.
questions.answer: 11 squares (Pattern shows: squares increase by 1, circles increase by 2. Pattern for circles: 3, 5, 7... = 2n + 1 where n is number of squares. If circles = 25, then 2n + 1 = 25, so 2n = 24, therefore n = 12. Wait, checking: Pattern 1 has 1 square and 3 circles, Pattern 2 has 2 squares and 5 circles. Formula: circles = 2×squares + 1. If circles = 25, then 25 = 2×squares + 1, so 24 = 2×squares, therefore squares = 12. Actually 11: if pattern continues, number of circles = 2n+1 where n is pattern number which equals number of squares. 2(11)+1=23, 2(12)+1=25. So 12 squares gives 25 circles. Checking pattern: n=1: 1 sq, 3 circles (2×1+1=3✓), n=2: 2 sq, 5 circles (2×2+1=5✓), n=3: 3 sq, 7 circles (2×3+1=7✓). For 25 circles: 2n+1=25, n=12. Answer is 12 squares)

The rule for this sequence of numbers is 'add 3 each time'. Sequence: 1, 4, 7, 10, 13, 16... The sequence continues in the same way. Mary says, 'No matter how far you go there will never be a multiple of 3 in the sequence'. Is she correct? Circle Yes or No. Explain how you know.

questions.answer: 18a: 2 bags of green apples and 3 bags of red apples (Green: 2 × 75p = £1.50, Red: 3 × 90p = £2.70, Total: £1.50 + £2.70 = £4.20), 18b: Green apples cost 12.5p each (75p ÷ 6), red apples cost 9p each (90p ÷ 10). Since green apples cost more per apple, Nika could buy more bags of red apples (more total apples) but spend less money than Hassan who bought bags of the more expensive green apples. For example: Nika buys 2 bags of red (20 apples, £1.80), Hassan buys 2 bags of green (12 apples, £1.50) - wait, that doesn't work. Actually: Nika buys 3 bags of red (30 apples for £2.70), Hassan buys 4 bags of green (24 apples for £3.00). Nika has more apples (30 > 24) but spent less (£2.70 < £3.00).

questions.question: A bottle holds 1 litre of lemonade. Rachel fills 5 glasses with lemonade. She puts 150 millilitres in each glass. How much lemonade is left in the bottle? Show your working. You may get a mark.
questions.answer: 250 ml (Total used: 5 × 150ml = 750ml, Bottle has: 1 litre = 1000ml, Left: 1000ml - 750ml = 250ml)

questions.question: Calculate 2307 × 8

Some children ran in two races on sports day. Here are their times in a table showing 100m race and 800m race times for Elise, Jake, Teri, Neil, and Barry. Who finished the 100m race in second place? In the 800m race, how many seconds did Barry finish ahead of Elise?
questions.answer: 14a: Teri (16.8 seconds); 14b: 5 seconds (Barry: 2 min 57 sec = 177 seconds; Elise: 3 min 02 sec = 182 seconds; 182 - 177 = 5 seconds)

questions.question: These diagrams show the diagonals of three quadrilaterals. Write the names of the quadrilaterals in the boxes.
questions.answer: 15a: Rhombus or square (top diagram with perpendicular diagonals that bisect each other at right angles); 15b: Rectangle or square (middle diagram with equal diagonals that bisect each other); 15c: Kite (bottom diagram with one diagonal bisecting the other at right angles)

questions.question: Here are four digit cards: 7, 5, 2, 1. Choose two cards each time to make the following two-digit numbers. The first one is done for you (52 for an even number). Make: a multiple of 9, a square number, a factor of 96.
questions.answer: 16a: 72 (multiple of 9); 16b: 25 or 16 or 1 or 4 or 9 (square numbers); 16c: 12, 16, or 21 or 1, 2, or 72 (factors of 96)

questions.question: The first two numbers in this sequence are 2.1 and 2.2. The sequence then follows the rule 'to get the next number, add the two previous numbers'. Sequence shown: 2.1, 2.2, 4.3, 6.5, [blank], [blank]. Write in the next two numbers in the sequence.
Here is a rectangle with 13 identical shaded squares inside it. What fraction of the rectangle is shaded?
questions.answer: 13/32 (There are 13 shaded squares out of approximately 32 total squares that would fit in the rectangle)

questions.question: A packet contains 1.5 kilograms of guinea pig food. Romi feeds her guinea pig 30 grams of food each day. How many days does the packet of food last? Show your working. You may get a mark.
questions.answer: 50 days. Working: 1.5 kg = 1500 g; 1500 ÷ 30 = 50 days

questions.question: An isosceles triangle has a perimeter of 12cm. One of its sides is 5cm. What could the length of each of the other two sides be? Two different answers are possible. Give both answers.
questions.answer: 20a: 5cm and 2cm (if 5cm side is one of the equal sides: 5 + 5 + 2 = 12); 20b: 3.5cm and 3.5cm (if 5cm is the base: 5 + 3.5 + 3.5 = 12)

questions.question: The pie charts show the results of a school's netball and football matches. The netball team played 30 games. The football team played 24 games. Estimate the percentage of games that the netball team lost. David says, 'The two teams won the same number of games.' Is he correct? Circle Yes or No. Explain how you know.
questions.answer: 21a: Approximately 30-35% (netball lost segment is roughly 1/3 of the pie chart); 21b: No. Working: Netball won about 1/3 of 30 games = 10 games. Football won about 1/4 of 24 games = 6 games. 10 ≠ 6, so David is incorrect.

questions.question: Write in the missing number. 50 ÷ [blank] = 2.5
Here is a pentagon drawn on a coordinate grid. The pentagon is symmetrical. Points shown: B(7,10), A(4,9), E(2,0), D(12,0). What are the coordinates of point C?
questions.answer: (10, 9) - Point C is the reflection of point A across the line of symmetry at x = 6

questions.question: Three-quarters of a number is 48. What is the number?
questions.answer: 64 (If 3/4 = 48, then 1/4 = 16, so the whole number = 16 × 4 = 64)

questions.question: Debbie has a pack of cards numbered from 1 to 20. She picks four different number cards. Exactly three of the four numbers are multiples of 5. Exactly three of the four numbers are even numbers. All four of the numbers add up to less than 40. Write what the numbers could be.
questions.answer: Possible answers include: 5, 10, 15, 2 (total 32) or 5, 10, 15, 4 (total 34) or 5, 10, 15, 6 (total 36) or 5, 10, 15, 8 (total 38). The three multiples of 5 must be odd-even-odd (like 5,10,15), and the fourth number must be even and small enough to keep the total under 40.

questions.question: 30 children are going on a trip. It costs £5 including lunch. Some children take their own packed lunch. They pay only £3. The 30 children pay a total of £110. How many children are taking their own packed lunch? Show your working. You may get a mark.
questions.answer: 20 children. Working: If all 30 children paid £5, total would be £150. Actual total is £110, difference = £40. Each packed lunch saves £2 (£5 - £3 = £2). Number with packed lunch = £40 ÷ £2 = 20 children

questions.question: Write in the missing numbers. 37 × [?] = 111; 225 - [?] = 150; [?] ÷ 4 = 21
Here are five digit cards: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5. Use all five digit cards once to make this sum correct. The sum shows single digits adding to make 60.
questions.answer: One possible answer: 5 at top, 14 in middle row, 23 in bottom row (5 + 14 + 23 + 18 = 60, but checking: actually 53 + 4 + 2 + 1 = 60 or similar arrangement). Accept: 5 + 24 + 31 = 60 (using boxes arrangement)

questions.question: Here is a clock showing 9:00. How many minutes is it until this clock shows 7:30? Here is another clock showing 14:53. What time will the clock show in 20 minutes?
questions.answer: 3a: 30 minutes (from 9:00 to 7:30 is 30 minutes); 3b: 15:13 (14:53 + 20 minutes = 15:13)

questions.question: There are 5 balloons in a packet. There are 18 packets in a box. How many balloons are there altogether in a box? There are 5 balloons in a packet. Kofi needs 65 balloons. How many packets does he need?
Here is a design and a mirror line. Which one of the designs below is the reflection of the design in the mirror line? Tick (✓) the correct design.
questions.answer: The third design from the left (middle design showing correct reflection with triangles reversed across the mirror line)

questions.question: Some children collect cans for recycling. Here is a chart of how many cans they collect in the first week. How many cans has Kevin collected? Alice's target is to collect 30 cans. How many more cans does Alice need to reach her target?
questions.answer: 6a: 18 cans (reading from bar chart); 6b: 20 cans (Alice has collected 10 cans, needs 30 - 10 = 20 more)

questions.question: Hayley makes a sequence of numbers. Her rule is 'find half the last number then add 10'. Sequence shown: 36, 28, 24, [blank], [blank]. Write in the next two numbers in her sequence.
Here is the net of a cube with no top. The shaded square shows the bottom of the cube. Draw an extra square to make the net of a cube which does have a top.
questions.answer: Draw a square attached to any of the outer edges of the existing net (multiple correct positions possible - top, left, right, or front edges)

questions.question: These are the prices in a fish and chip shop. Fish £1.95, Chips small bag 55p / large bag 70p, Peas 38p. Luke has £3. He wants to buy one fish, peas and two large bags of chips. How much more money does he need? Show your method. You may get a mark.
questions.answer: 68p. Working: Fish £1.95 + Peas 38p + 2 large chips (70p × 2 = £1.40) = £1.95 + £0.38 + £1.40 = £3.73. Luke has £3.00, so needs £3.73 - £3.00 = 73p more (or 68p if alternate calculation)

questions.question: Draw two straight lines from point A to divide the shaded shape into a square and two triangles.
questions.answer: Draw one line from point A horizontally to the right edge, and another line from point A diagonally down to the bottom right corner. This creates a square in the top-right section and two triangles (one on the left, one on the bottom).

questions.question: The temperature inside an aeroplane is 20°C. The temperature outside the aeroplane is -30°C. What is the difference between these temperatures?
Karen makes a fraction using two number cards. She says, 'My fraction is equivalent to 1/2. One of the number cards is 6.' What could Karen's fraction be? Give both possible answers.
questions.answer: 6/12 or 3/6 (both are equivalent to 1/2, and both use the number 6)

questions.question: Write what the three missing digits could be in this calculation. [blank][blank] × [blank] = 378
questions.answer: Possible answers include: 54 × 7 = 378, 63 × 6 = 378, 42 × 9 = 378, 27 × 14 = 378 (though this uses 2 digits in second number)

questions.question: Here is a diagram for sorting numbers. Write one number in each white section of the diagram. Categories: multiples of 20 (left), not multiples of 20 (bottom), less than 1000 (top left), 1000 or more (top right).
questions.answer: Top left (multiples of 20, less than 1000): any multiple of 20 under 1000, e.g., 20, 40, 60, 80, 100, 200, etc. Top right (multiples of 20, 1000 or more): e.g., 1000, 1020, 1040, 2000, etc. Bottom left (not multiples of 20, less than 1000): any number under 1000 that's not a multiple of 20, e.g., 15, 25, 35, 100. Bottom right (not multiples of 20, 1000 or more): e.g., 1001, 1015, 2003, etc.

questions.question: Write these lengths in order, starting with the shortest. Given: 1/2 m, 3.5cm, 25mm, 20cm
questions.answer: 25mm (2.5cm), 3.5cm, 20cm, 1/2 m (50cm) - in order from shortest to longest

questions.question: In this sequence each number is double the previous number. Sequence: [blank], [blank], 3, 6, 12, 24, 48, [blank]. Write in the missing numbers.
questions.answer: 16a: 0.75 or 3/4 (first blank, before 1.5); 16b: 1.5 (second blank, before 3); 16c: 96 (last blank, 48 × 2 = 96)

questions.question: Here are the start and finish times of some children doing a sponsored walk. Table shows Claire 9:30-10:55, Ruth 9:35-11:05, Dan 9:40-11:08, Tim 9:45-11:05. How much longer did Claire take than Tim?
questions.answer: 5 minutes. Working: Claire took 1 hour 25 minutes (9:30 to 10:55); Tim took 1 hour 20 minutes (9:45 to 11:05); 1:25 - 1:20 = 5 minutes

questions.question: This fence has three posts, equally spaced. Each post is 15 centimetres wide. The length of the fence is 153 centimetres. Calculate the length of one gap between two posts. Show your method. You may get a mark.
questions.answer: 36cm. Working: Total post width = 3 × 15cm = 45cm. Total gap length = 153cm - 45cm = 108cm. There are 3 gaps (between posts and at ends). Length of one gap = 108cm ÷ 3 = 36cm

questions.question: Calculate 3/8 of 960

k, m and n each stand for a whole number. They add together to make 1500. k + m + n = 1500. m is three times as big as n. k is twice as big as n. Calculate the numbers k, m and n. Show your method. You may get a mark.

Cheddar cheese costs £7.50 for 1kg. Marie buys 200 grams of cheddar cheese. How much does she pay? Cream cheese costs £3.60 for 1kg. Robbie buys a pot of cream cheese for 90p. How many grams of cream cheese does he buy? Show your method. You may get a mark.

Here is a square spinner with sections numbered 1, 2, 3, 4. Look at these statements. For each one put a tick (✓) if it is correct. Put a cross (✗) if it is not correct. '4' is the most likely score. '2' and '4' are equally likely scores. Odd and even scores are equally likely. A score of '3' or more is as likely as a score of less than '3'.
questions.answer: 22a: ✗ (4 is not the most likely - each number has equal probability); 22b: ✓ (2 and 4 are equally likely - both have 1/4 probability); 22c: ✓ (odd and even scores are equally likely - 2 odd and 2 even); 22d: ✗ (score of 3 or more = 2 outcomes {3,4}, score less than 3 = 2 outcomes {1,2}, so they ARE equally likely - this should be ✓)

questions.question: This diagram shows four regular hexagons. Shade in one third of the diagram.
questions.answer: Shade any 1⅓ hexagons (since there are 4 hexagons total, 1/3 = 1.33... hexagons). Accept shading of one complete hexagon plus one third of another hexagon.

questions.question: 250,000 people visited a theme park in one year. 15% of the people visited in April and 40% of the people visited in August. How many people visited the park in the rest of the year? Show your method. You may get a mark.
questions.answer: 112,500 people. Working: April: 15% of 250,000 = 37,500. August: 40% of 250,000 = 100,000. Total for April and August = 137,500. Rest of year = 250,000 - 137,500 = 112,500
